sections.title: What are we comparing?
sections.content:
**Past simple** (I went, she did, they saw) describes completed actions or events at a specific time in the past. **Past continuous** (I was going, she was doing, they were watching) describes an action **in progress** at a moment in the past – it was happening over a period, often when something else happened.

• Past simple: **did** / **went** / **saw** (completed)
• Past continuous: **was/were + -ing** (in progress)

sections.title: When we use Past Simple
sections.content:
Use the **past simple** when:

• The action or event is **completed** in the past: I finished the report. She left at five.
• We talk about a **specific time** (yesterday, last week, at 3 o'clock, when...): I saw him yesterday. What did you do last night?
• We tell a **sequence of events**: I got up, had breakfast, and went to work.
• Short actions that **interrupt** a longer action: The phone rang while I was cooking. (rang = past simple)

Form: regular verbs → **-ed**; irregular verbs → past form (went, saw, wrote).

sections.title: When we use Past Continuous
sections.content:
Use the **past continuous** when:

• An action was **in progress** at a moment in the past: At 8 pm I was watching TV. (I had started and was in the middle of it.)
• We describe **background** or **longer** action when something else happened: I **was walking** home when I **met** an old friend. (walking = in progress; met = the event)
• Two actions in progress at the same time (parallel): She **was cooking** while he **was setting** the table.
• To show that something was **temporary** or **in progress** then: Last year she was working in London.

Form: **was/were + verb + -ing** (was reading, were playing).

sections.title: Interrupted actions: when and while
sections.content:
When one action **interrupts** another:

• The **longer** action (in progress) → **past continuous**: I **was reading** when the phone rang.
• The **shorter** or **interrupting** action → **past simple**: I was reading when the phone **rang**.

With **while** we often use past continuous for the action that was in progress:
• **While** I **was cooking**, she **was setting** the table. (both in progress)
• **While** she **was working**, the phone **rang**. (working = background; rang = event)

**When** can be followed by past simple or past continuous: When I **arrived** (past simple), they **were having** dinner (past continuous).

sections.title: Quick summary
sections.content:
• **Past simple** – completed actions, specific past time, sequence of events, short interrupting action. (did, went, saw)
• **Past continuous** – action in progress at a moment in the past, background action, two parallel actions. (was/were + -ing)
• **Interrupted:** Long action = past continuous; short event = past simple. (I was reading when the phone rang.)
• **While** – often past continuous for the action in progress. **When** – past simple for the event, past continuous for the background.

sections.title: Typical learner errors
sections.content:
• **Using past simple for an action in progress:** Wrong: *I read when the phone rang.* (if you mean you were in the middle of reading) Right: **I was reading when the phone rang.**
• **Using past continuous for a short completed action:** Wrong: *The phone was ringing when I was reading.* (if the phone rang once) Right: **The phone rang when I was reading.**
• **Using past continuous for a finished time:** Wrong: *I was going to the cinema yesterday.* (if you mean you went and it's done) Right: **I went to the cinema yesterday.**
• **Using two past simples for interrupted action:** Wrong: *I read when she called.* (unclear; were you in the middle of reading?) Right: **I was reading when she called.**

Tip: In progress at a moment = past continuous. Completed event or specific time = past simple.

questions.question: 'I _____ TV when the phone rang.' (You were in the middle of watching.) Which fits?
questions.explanation: Action in progress when something else happened → past continuous.

questions.question: 'She _____ to London yesterday.' (Completed trip.) Which fits?
questions.explanation: Completed action, specific time (yesterday) → past simple.

questions.question: 'While he _____ dinner, I was reading.' Which fits?
questions.explanation: Two actions in progress at the same time → past continuous for both.

questions.question: 'The doorbell _____ while I was having a shower.' Which fits?
questions.explanation: Short interrupting event → past simple.

questions.question: 'At 7 pm last night they _____ .' (They were in the middle of eating.) Which fits?
questions.explanation: Action in progress at a specific moment → past continuous.

gapfill.title: Practice: Past simple or past continuous?

questions.question: I _____ (watch) TV when the phone rang.
questions.explanation: Action in progress when something happened → past continuous.

questions.question: I was watching TV when the phone _____ (ring).
questions.explanation: Short interrupting event → past simple.

questions.question: She _____ (go) to the cinema yesterday.
questions.explanation: Completed action, yesterday → past simple.

questions.question: While he _____ (cook), she was setting the table.
questions.explanation: Two actions in progress at the same time → past continuous.

questions.question: We _____ (have) dinner at 8 pm last night.
questions.explanation: Action in progress at a moment (at 8 pm) → past continuous.

questions.question: He _____ (walk) home when he met an old friend.
questions.explanation: Background action in progress → past continuous.

questions.question: They _____ (not watch) the film when I arrived.
questions.explanation: Action in progress (negative) when I arrived → past continuous.

questions.question: What _____ you _____ (do) when the lights went out?
questions.explanation: What were you in the middle of → past continuous.

questions.question: I saw him while I _____ (wait) for the bus.
questions.explanation: Action in progress (background) → past continuous.

questions.question: The phone _____ (ring) while I was having a shower.
questions.explanation: Short interrupting event → past simple.

questions.question: She _____ (work) in Paris last year.
questions.explanation: Temporary situation or completed → was working or worked.

questions.question: Wrong: 'I read when the phone rang.' (You mean you were in the middle of reading.) Correct the sentence.
answers: I was reading when the phone rang.
I was reading when the phone rang
questions.explanation: Action in progress → past continuous (was reading).

questions.question: Wrong: 'She was going to London yesterday.' (She went; the trip is completed.) Correct the sentence.
questions.explanation: Completed action with yesterday → past simple.

questions.question: Wrong: 'The phone was ringing when I was reading.' (The phone rang once and interrupted you.) Correct the sentence.
answers: The phone rang when I was reading.
The phone rang when I was reading
questions.explanation: Short interrupting event → past simple (rang).

questions.question: Wrong: 'While he cooked, she set the table.' (Both were in progress at the same time.) Correct using past continuous where appropriate.
answers: While he was cooking, she was setting the table.
While he was cooking, she was setting the table
questions.explanation: Two parallel actions in progress → past continuous for both.

questions.question: Wrong: 'I was seeing him yesterday.' (You met him once; completed.) Correct the sentence.
questions.explanation: Completed event, yesterday → past simple (saw).

questions.question: Wrong: 'We had dinner at 8 pm.' (You mean you were in the middle of dinner at that moment.) Correct the sentence.
answers: We were having dinner at 8 pm.
We were having dinner at 8 pm
questions.explanation: Action in progress at a moment → past continuous.
